item.title: Comment on *Unit X* by a bar or a bat, was it
item.description:
Obviously we can't read this as-yet unpublished book, but I bet it only addresses a fraction of the overall issues.

Silicon Valley bit-wranglers have total dependence on Asian atom-wranglers. The folks at Apple who design chips and iPhones need Taiwanese foundries and Chinese factories to actually make them physical.

Evolving a manufacturing ecosystem onshore is no trivial or quick task. Throwing money at it won't do the trick, all the more so if that CHIPS funding is tied to a million wishful sociopolitical and pork-barrel agendas. The effort needs decades and is already off on the wrong foot.

Above all you need to manufacture cheaply on a massive scale, with scant regard for environmental impact externalities. The Pentagon only knows how to make ridiculously expensive stuff. With extreme asymmetries of expense, you end up losing a war of cost attrition. Arguably that's what happened in Afghanistan. It also explains the failure in the Red Sea: you can't afford to shoot down every single dirt-cheap drone with a million-dollar missile.

In Ukraine, innovation is exemplified by the glide bomb: a hybrid of Chinese-tech-enabled "glide" guidance smarts and massive Russian capacity to build and stockpile stuff that goes boom. I suspect this book is all about merely designing the first kind of thing, and not actually making both at scale and on budget.

item.title: Comment on Why prediction markets are not popular by Kaleberg
item.description:
Just about every financial market is a prediction market. Economists have been writing about it for ages. In traditional prediction markets, the bet is made by lending money, contracting for future delivery or buying a share of an enterprise.

What is called a prediction market here is basically old fashioned book making. One is betting on being correct in one's prediction, not in simply getting one's money back with interest, a supply of some commodity at a fixed price or a share of a more valuable enterprise.

People bet on predictions all the time. You can bet on horse races, elections, football games, and probably anything else. This appeals to gamblers, but gamblers want to get their rush in a timely manner. It only works when one is betting maybe a few weeks out, but ideally less.
